articles.headline: Should Robots Have a Face?
articles.snippet: As automation comes to retail industries, companies are giving machines more humanlike features in order to make them liked, not feared.
articles.abstract: As automation comes to retail industries, companies are giving machines more humanlike features in order to make them liked, not feared.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tina Sorg first saw the robot rolling through her Giant supermarket in Harrisburg, Pa., she said to herself, “That thing is a little weird.”

articles.headline: Up to 91% More Expensive: How Delivery Apps Eat Up Your Budget
articles.snippet: Uber Eats, DoorDash and Postmates might be convenient, but the apps are making you pay a juicy premium.
articles.abstract: Uber Eats, DoorDash and Postmates might be convenient, but the apps are making you pay a juicy premium.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a long day, you have probably done some back-of-the-napkin math and decided there was no point in going out for dinner when you could get food brought to your door for the same cost, plus a tip. So you fired up a delivery app.

articles.headline: Freaked Out by the Stock Market? Take a Deep Breath
articles.snippet: When the stock market shudders a few days in a row, it is tempting to do something, and fast. Read this first.
articles.abstract: When the stock market shudders a few days in a row, it is tempting to do something, and fast. Read this first.
articles.lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

articles.headline: ‘He Hasn’t Been Here’: Why Joe Biden Lags in Super Tuesday States
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is counting on a victory in South Carolina to revive his candidacy. But a daunting challenge awaits next week in states where he has limited resources.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is counting on a victory in South Carolina to revive his candidacy. But a daunting challenge awaits next week in states where he has limited resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the day before in-person early voting was to begin across California’s most populous county, there was no sign of life at Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign office in East Los Angeles last Friday. A metal gate out front was padlocked shut, with a missed-delivery notice from the Postal Service wedged into it.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: The Roots of the Delhi Riots: A Fiery Speech and an Ultimatum
articles.snippet: A local Hindu politician told the police to evict a group of Muslim protesters or he and his men would. Now, 25 have died in some of the worst violence in years.
articles.abstract: A local Hindu politician told the police to evict a group of Muslim protesters or he and his men would. Now, 25 have died in some of the worst violence in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — To many in the eastern Delhi neighborhood where a convulsion of religious violence erupted this week, it all began with one man.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Suhasini Raj and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: 1,000 Workers, Go Home: Companies Act to Ward Off Coronavirus
articles.snippet: In Europe, corporate emergency plans are forcing employees to work remotely, and other businesses are refining their protocols for when the illness arrives on their doorstep.
articles.abstract: In Europe, corporate emergency plans are forcing employees to work remotely, and other businesses are refining their protocols for when the illness arrives on their doorstep.
articles.lead_paragraph: An oil company and a media group have told hundreds of employees in London to work from home. A television giant is stopping people who have visited certain countries from entering its offices in Europe. A German airline has asked workers to take unpaid leave.

articles.headline: Center Stage at Disney After a Career Out of the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Bob Chapek, the company’s new chief executive, does not remind anyone of his predecessor, Bob Iger. And that might be fine.
articles.abstract: Bob Chapek, the company’s new chief executive, does not remind anyone of his predecessor, Bob Iger. And that might be fine.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The second that Robert A. Iger stepped down as Disney’s chief executive on Tuesday — almost two years sooner than expected — Hollywood broke into frenzied gossip.

articles.headline: Trump Has a Problem as the Coronavirus Threatens the U.S.: His Credibility
articles.snippet: Even his allies worry that President Trump has undermined his ability to appear presidential in a moment of national emergency.
articles.abstract: Even his allies worry that President Trump has undermined his ability to appear presidential in a moment of national emergency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Hurricane Dorian crashed into the Atlantic Coast in September, President Trump assumed a take-charge role in response. But he undermined his own effectiveness after it became apparent that before displaying a map in front of the television cameras in the Oval Office, he had altered it with a Sharpie pen to match his inaccurate forecast of where the storm was headed.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Michael Crowley and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: As Coronavirus Slams Small Business, a Noodle Shop Fights for Life
articles.snippet: China’s entrepreneurs, essential to the economy, have seen their fortunes plummet. Many millions of jobs are at stake.
articles.abstract: China’s entrepreneurs, essential to the economy, have seen their fortunes plummet. Many millions of jobs are at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The stone counters where customers normally crowd at Pang Mei’s Noodle Shop in Beijing have been turned into an assembly line of workers folding dumplings or measuring out noodles, sauces and other ingredients into plastic containers.

articles.headline: Democratic Leaders Willing to Risk Party Damage to Stop Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: Interviews with dozens of Democratic Party officials, including 93 superdelegates, found overwhelming opposition to handing Mr. Sanders the nomination if he fell short of a majority of delegates.
articles.abstract: Interviews with dozens of Democratic Party officials, including 93 superdelegates, found overwhelming opposition to handing Mr. Sanders the nomination if he fell short of a majority of delegates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, hear constant warnings from allies about congressional losses in November if the party nominates Bernie Sanders for president. Democratic House members share their Sanders fears on text-messaging chains. Bill Clinton, in calls with old friends, vents about the party getting wiped out in the general election.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Scarred and Weary, an Afghan Force Wonders: What Is Peace?
articles.snippet: A truce is prompting introspection. “Who is it on the other side?” mused a 15-year veteran of intimate warfare. “They are not even from a different district.”
articles.abstract: A truce is prompting introspection. “Who is it on the other side?” mused a 15-year veteran of intimate warfare. “They are not even from a different district.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JELDAK, Afghanistan — Their young bodies are as broken as the bomb-pocked 40 miles of highway they guard.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Kiana Hayeri

articles.headline: Coronavirus Fears Drive Stocks Down for 6th Day and Into Correction
articles.snippet: The virus, which has now spread to 47 countries, has put pressure on businesses and supply chains around the world.
articles.abstract: The virus, which has now spread to 47 countries, has put pressure on businesses and supply chains around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global stock market slid for the sixth straight day on Thursday, as the S&P 500 index plunged to its worst loss in almost nine years and investors worldwide grew increasingly fearful that the coronavirus outbreak could cause a recession as it squeezes corporate profits.
